displayText: Right welcome to the first meeting of Real Reaction's development meetings for our new television remote control. This follows our very successful entry into the consumer market over the last year or so which we want to build on, taking advantage of the the latest developments in technology and the latest feelings in consumer design and demand we want to make this the the very best product that's possible for everybody, one that everybody wants, at a good price for the consumer and at a good price for the company. And to that end we need all to work together to do that. And in no particular order because everybody is just as vital to this project I'll just go round the table, Andrew, marketing, Kendra with designing the the User Interface and Kate with the industrial design. Mm. Um. What's the project is here to do, is to get this project up and moving, everybody is free to say whatever they want, everybody has a contribution to make and everybody feel free to interrupt me at any time to say what you want to say. In terms of the immediate meeting everybody knows everybody else, everybody's worked for the company for a while, if anybody feels that they need to say more about themselves please do, if if anybody wants to briefly give their background so that everybody's quite clear what everybody's experience is please do so. In fact I'd I'd welcome anybody to say something briefly about themselves, in fact we will do that by going round the table quickly and saying what contribution you're looking to make. So we'll start with Andrew. My name's Andrew I'm the Market Research person for this meeting and this project for creating this new remote control I'll be presenting information statistics on what people want to want to get from this new design, what people want to like and from a fashion point of view and the practicality point of view. Right Kendra. I'm Kendra and I'm the User Interface Designer and I haven't had a whole lot of experience in this kind of thing before but I'll be working on the design. Okay, very very quickly, I don't want to make this meeting too structured because the whole idea is that it's a think tank. Everybody says what they want to say, and we don't want to be constrained by kind of convention or slides on screens or anything else but briefly this is what we want to do. The remote control needs to be original, there has to be something about it that other remote controls don't have so that as soon as people see it they think yes that's different, I want one, and that goes along with being trendy, the I want it scenario. User-friendly as we all know, remote controls can be very user-unfriendly so we want to make ours one that people can pick up and think yes it's obvious how that works, and they also want to look at the price and think that's something that I may not need another remote control but it's such a nice one I'm gonna have one. And last but not least, or indeed first of all, it it must make the company money, and we make the company money by producing what the consumer wants. The further work to be done is the functional design, what it must actually do, the conceptual design, how we actually present that to the consumer and the detailed design is how we get that into production. I'm not sure that I've got any favourite animal to be quite honest, homo sapien because of their overall ability to Sorry? It needs to cost twelve Euros fifty to make. So a very trendy original product, we're looking at making it at a very good price. Any other thoughts about the physical appearance of remote controls? I think something that's comfortable to hold because sometimes you get the remote controls that are just those big, rectangular things and they're kind of awkward to hold onto, so something that's more comfortable that fits in a person's hand better. Mm. Mm. The thing that immediately comes to mind is computer mouses which you get all sorts of shapes in the shops and some quite fancy ones than some from personal experience which look nice but aren't particularly comfortable. Mm. Yeah. Yeah. Mm. Yeah. Yeah. Mm-hmm, especially if we try to sell, what two million of them. Mm. Mm-hmm. I think this is gonna have to appeal to people that want device that can enhance their living room but also a device that is practically sound. Mm-hmm. Mm-hmm. Indeed. Yeah. But so yes dependable, and have a good medium range size. Okay, and colours, materials? Kendra, anyone? I think most of the remote controls now are either just black or grey, so maybe we should go with something different or be able to I was just thinking of what they're doing with mobile phones now how you can get the different what are they called? The face-plates that you change so we could have maybe I don't know if it would be feasible to do something with that, where you can change the face-plates or have kind of a variety so people can get different things. Yeah. Mm, mm-hmm. Uh-huh. Have it kind of look how they want to, different colours, things like that, probably just plastic because that's always the lightest. Right. Yeah. Okay Again I don't think that's ever been done before, it's the sort of thing that would get people thinking yes that's something that I haven't got and might need so. Mm-hmm. Andrew, any thoughts about how we might market interchangeable fronts on the remote control? We could either market it together by getting control in a set colour or with you buy it with several you get the face-plates with it when you buy or as a separate thing, but maybe thinking of that, it's considering the nature of the device, maybe a second thing like a second campaign to market new facials to your might go a bit astray since it is the kind of thing where you generally get one and then forget about it. Mm. Yeah. Unless you were trying to Mm. Yeah. I think Mm-mm. Yeah. That's a that's a good idea. Yeah. Mm. Right, okay I think we've got a good idea now. True. We Needs to be wrapped up fairly quickly.
